datasetPresenter.name: ehisRahman_primary_genome_RSRC

datasetPresenter.description: Genome Assembly for Entamoeba histolytica Rahman strain was provided by Gareth Weedall and Neil Hall. Institute of Integrative Biology, University of Liverpool, Crown Street, Liverpool L69 7ZB, UK

datasetPresenter.name: enutP19_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Entamoeba nuttalli P19 Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.description: The sequence and annotation of Entamoeba nuttalli P19 were produced at the J. Craig Venter Institute to a sequencing depth of coverage is 78X using Illumina sequencing methods. Data were downloaded from GenBank.
datasetPresenter.usage: Sequence and annotation can be searched based on a variety of parameters such as genomic location, gene ID and BLAST similarity (for a full list of queries see the Searches using these data section below). The sequence and annotation can be viewed in GBrowse along with any functional data that maps to it.

datasetPresenter.name: ehisDS4_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: E. histolytica DS4 Genome from JCVI
datasetPresenter.description:
Reference assembly for E. histolytica DS4 obtained from Lis Caler at the J. Craig Venter Institute (JCVI).
Users should acknowledge the J. Craig Venter Institute and the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, National Institutes of Health, Department of Health and Human Services in any publications that result from use of this draft sequence assembly. Any investigaors who propose to publish analyses of the sequence/open reading frames/genes on a genome scale should contact the J. Craig Venter Institute for the use of pre-publication data.

You can download a poster describing the sequencing of these clinical isolates here.

datasetPresenter.name: ehisHM1IMSS_microarrayExpression_Gilchrist_GSE28883_G3-HM1_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: E. histolytica G3 v. HM1:IMSS Transcript Expression Array Profiles
datasetPresenter.description:
Changes in the transcriptome of Entamoeba histolytica accompany the epigenetic silencing of the amoebapore gene In E. histolytica G3 transfectants, transcriptional silencing of the amoebapore gene (Ehap-a) is accompanied by the down-regulation of two other members of the saposin-like (SAPLIP) gene family (Ehap-b, and EhSaplip1). In the current work, comparison of the G3 transcriptome with that of the parent HM-1:IMSS strain has identified an additional 12 transcripts that were down regulated and 60 which were upregulated at least 7 fold. To investigate this phenomena in more depth, one of the transcripts (TIGR 459.m00030) which was increased >200 fold was further investigated. This E. histolytica specific transcript has the potential to encode a 66 amino acid protein however antibodies raised against a synthetic N-terminal peptide of the 459.m gene did not recognize any such protein in either G3 or HM-1:IMSS amoeba lysates. Treatment of G3 transfectants with the proteasome inhibitor MG-132 to prevent rapid 459.m protein degradation did not result in any detectable 459.m protein. Neither did the transfection of the parent HM-1:IMSS with an expression construct in which the Ehactin gene promoter was used to greatly increase the level of the 459.m transcript. However, transfectants in which the 459.m ORF sequence was placed downstream the GST gene, expressed a fused protein. To determine if the increase in this non-coding mRNA were due to changes in the stability of the 459.m transcript or increased transcription, reporter constructs were generated. The reporter gene was both placed directly 3' of the 459.m gene promoter or fused to the C-terminal sequence of the 459.m ORF. The 459.m promoter, in isolation, was weak and no difference in reporter expression was observed in either G3 or HM-1:IMSS transfectants. The genetic context of the 459.m gene was examined and retroposon elements (EhERE1 and EhSINE) were discovered downstream suggesting the possibility of their involvement in the observed transcription changes.

Authors: Rivka Bracha, Carol A. Gilchrist and David Mirelman

templateInjector.prop: Sample Type 1. G3 (Ehap-a silenced strain) 2. HM1:IMSS (Parent strain)
RMA Normalized Values (log base 2) or expression percentile value.

datasetPresenter.name: ehisHM1IMSS_microarrayExpression_Gilchrist_Singh_intestinal_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: E. histolytica HM-1:IMSS Intestinal Colonization/Invasion and Stage Conversion Array Profiles
datasetPresenter.description:
Gilchrist CA, Houpt E, Trapaidze N, Fei Z et al. Impact of intestinal colonization and invasion on the Entamoeba histolytica transcriptome. Mol Biochem Parasitol 2006 Jun;147(2):163-76. PMID: 16569449
Ehrenkaufer GM, Haque R, Hackney JA, Eichinger DJ et al. Identification of developmentally regulated genes in Entamoeba histolytica: insights into mechanisms of stage conversion in a protozoan parasite. Cell Microbiol 2007 Jun;9(6):1426-44. PMID: 17250591

Taken from GEO datasets: GSE8484,GSE6648

templateInjector.prop: RMA Normalized Values (log base 2) or expression percentile value.

datasetPresenter.name: ehisHM1IMSS_SNP_Weedall_SOLID_htsSNPs_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: E. Histolytica strain HTS sequence reads
datasetPresenter.description: ABI SOLiD sequence reads of multiple E. histolytica strains were provided by Gareth Weedall and Neil Hall, of the Institute of Integrative Biology, Liverpool. Reads were aligned to the E. histolytica HM-1:IMSS reference genome using Bowtie and SNPs called using VarScan.

templateInjector.prop: 2592100 HK9 IULA MS27 MS84PVB PVF Rahman

datasetPresenter.name: ehisHM1IMSS_massSpec_Marion_Proteomics_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Human Serum Coated Magnetic Bead-Purified Phagosomes from Trophozoite
datasetPresenter.summary: Human Serum Coated Magnetic Bead-Purified Phagosomes from Trophozoite
datasetPresenter.description:
Human Serum Coated Magnetic Bead-Purified Phagosomes from Trophozoite (Marion et. al.)
Phagosomes were purified from E. histolytica wild type and myosin IB over-expressing (MyoIB+) trophozoites using human serum-coated magnetic beads. Phagosomes from wild type parasites were purified following a 3 minute incubation with beads, and phagosomes from MyoIB+ parasites were purified following 5 or 15 minute incubations. Proteins were analyzed by liquid chromatography and tandem mass spectrometry (LC-MS/MS).

datasetPresenter.name: ehisHM1IMSS_massSpec_Glycosylation_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Concanavalin A-enriched Glycoproteins from Trophozoite
datasetPresenter.description:
Concanavalin A-enriched Glycoproteins from Trophozoite (Carpentieri et. al.)
Total protein extract (soluble fraction) from E. histolytica trophozoites was purified over a Concanavalin A column followed by tryptic digestions and N-glycanase F hydrolysis (to release N-linked glycans and identify glycosylation sites). Proteins were analyzed by liquid chromatography and tandem mass spectrometry (LC-MS/MS).

datasetPresenter.name: ehisHM1IMSS_massSpec_Markiewicz_Proteomics_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Purified Uropods from Trophozoite
datasetPresenter.description:
Purified Uropods from Trophozoite (Markiewicz et. al.)
Uropod extruded fractions were purified following a Concanavalin A incubation of E. histolytica trophozoites. Purification was performed by successive centrifugation and final pellet was processed for proteomics analysis. Proteins were analyzed by liquid chromatography and tandem mass spectrometry (LC-MS/MS).

datasetPresenter.name: ehisHM1IMSS_massSpec_Huston_phagosome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Phagosome Proteomics data
datasetPresenter.description:
Magnetic Bead-Purified Phagosomes from Trophozoite (Boettner et. al.)
Ingested carboxylated magnetic beads within intact phagosomes from E. histolytica were separated from amebic lysate and subjected to delipidation and mass spectrometry sequencing. Phagosome preparations were performed at 0, 5, 10, and 60 minutes following centrifugation of the beads into contact with trophozoites. In addition lysed ameba were incubated with beads and subjected to the same steps to account for background binding to the carboxylated beads. This resultant proteome identified many proteins previously associated with phagocytosis in the literature, including: the galactose binding lectin, small GTPases, hydrolytic proteins, cytoskeleton proteins, and endoplasmic reticulum proteins.
For details refer to: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18208324

datasetPresenter.name: (.*)_genomeFeature_repeatElements_GFF3_RSRC$
datasetPresenter.summary: Repetitive Elements in the Genome
datasetPresenter.description:
Repeat elements in Entamoeba (LINE, SINE, ERE).
Repeat elements were mapped in Entamoeba species: E. histolytica HM-1:MMS, E. invadens IP1, and E. dispar SAW760. SINE elements = Short INterspersed repetitive Elements, LINE elements = Long INterspersed repetitive Element, ERE = Entamoeba repeat element.
datasetPresenter.usage: These data are available as a GBrowse track and can be displayed in context with the genome.
